Design evaluation and modification of mechanical systems in virtual environments
Download PDF
Download PDF
  • Original Article
  • Published: 04 May 2007

Design evaluation and modification of mechanical systems in virtual environments

  • Csaba Antonya1 &
  • Doru Talaba1 

Virtual Reality volume 11, pages275–285(2007)Cite this article

  • 299 Accesses

  • 15 Citations

  • Metrics details

Abstract

Design is one of the most important stages in the manufacturing cycle and influences all the subsequent stages of product development. In the context of today’s iterative design methodology, the modification of any design is a process involving many evaluations and improvements to the solutions chosen in earlier stages. For this purpose, in the most recent decade, 3D computer simulations have become common tools used within industry. Whilst virtual reality (VR) technology is seen as the interaction technology of the future, much of the current research in this area is carried out to explore the potential benefits and added value brought by the integration of this into standard software technologies currently used at various stages in manufacturing life cycle. A lot of attention has been given to exploring the usability and benefits of interactive VR for assembly planning, knowledge elicitation and design and simulation. However, little research has focussed on the analytical aspects of the design process, for example in the use of VR as an interface for simulation software in finite element methods and multi-body systems. This paper introduces research focussing on applications of virtual environments (VEs) for interactive design evaluation and modification adapted and used with standard simulation software. The use of such interactive visualisation offers the engineer more realistic real-time representations of the design and advanced facilities to interact with the model during the design process. While design evaluation is based mainly on visualisation; design modification requires interactive changes of the model during the simulation, and the interfaces described here highlights such applications. In this work, two software prototypes have been developed using VR technology. First, a software tool called design evaluation in virtual environments is presented together with an application in civil engineering to illustrate the mode of operation and added value of the use of an interactive visualisation environment. Linking the simulation software with the VE provides real time bi-directional communication of graphical information which can be successfully achieved even within the limits of current computer technology. The tool includes a suite of software modules and a user interface to facilitate the link between the simulation results and the VE. The second tool facilitates the design modification in virtual environments system by providing real time dynamic simulation. Two dynamic approaches are investigated in order to study the real time simulation issues in the context of design modification and system performance: the classic approach based on rigid interconnected bodies, and a new and novel approach developed by the authors based on particles dynamics. Both implementations have been tested and compared on a mechanism application under the same computing conditions. The research applications presented demonstrate the practicality, flexibility and versatility of the visualisation in virtual environment in design evaluation and modification. However, the computer efficiency whilst carrying out real time dynamic simulation is limiting the range of applications to models of moderate size; however, this is an improvement on previous similar applications.

Introduction

Virtual environments (VE) can be used as effective tools in many manufacturing-related processes. Visualisation in VEs is the use of computer graphics to create visual images that aid in the understanding of and interaction with 3D models during various processes, like manufacturing. In the case of design and manufacturing applications, this may be based on the output of real-time numerical simulations or on using data from pre-recorded scenarios. Non-immersive interactive visualisation systems implemented with conventional desktop and mouse are effective for moderate complex problems, whereas VR potentially provides a richer set of spatial and depth cues with significant added value for complex applications (Grant and Lai 1998; Ritchie et al. 2002; Sanchez-Segura et al. 2004).

Some virtual prototyping tools based on conventional multi-body system (MBS) software, e.g. ADAMS, potentially offers parameterisation and design evaluation but usually compare the results using outputs such as graphics, tables of data or graphic animations. However, from the user viewpoint, interacting with virtual worlds and the provision of the realistic behaviour of objects is very important. Realistic behaviour can help to achieve consistency and predictability during the design process, especially when dealing with the design of mechanical systems. VR technology is seen as the interaction technology of the future, and most of the recent research has been carried out to explore the potential benefits and added value brought by the engineering process in integrating this with current standard software technologies. Much research effort has been given to exploring the usability and benefits of VR for assembly planning, knowledge elicitation and design. However, little research has been carried out into VR as an interface for conventional analytical simulation software applications, a key part of the product engineering process, e.g. in the areas of finite element methods (FEM) and MBSs. Linking simulation and VR is likely to enhance the design process by offering powerful tools to enable quick design and manufacturing process evaluation and modification. This paper presents some design evaluation and modification applications developed by the authors to illustrate the important issues in such an approach.

Interaction plays a very important role in VR, with devices such as immersive visualisation and haptic systems, providing users with powerful new interfaces to interact with digital models in 3D. Interactive systems, in software terms, are traditionally associated with the relationship between the user and the virtual product through the system’s interface (Sanchez-Segura et al. 2004). In particular, VR interfaces allow the rapid, interactive and intuitive exploration of simulations, enabling phenomena at various places in the design space to be assessed. However, interactivity requires real-time processing and this becomes the main limitation when integration with simulation is sought.

Nowadays, with regard to analytical applications, multi-body dynamics (MBD) and physically-based simulations are important tools in design and manufacturing simulation processes because they facilitate the evaluation of the physical behaviour of systems before a prototype is executed and tested. Commercial software packages available on the market are now standard tools used in the manufacturing domain for control and simulation applications. Potentially, using VR to interact with a simulation could provide significant enhancement to the engineer’s understanding of the problem and its associated solution. However, these technologies are drastically limited in terms of the real-time processing capabilities of conventional simulation tools.

Many VR applications for design and manufacture have been researched (Grant and Lai 1998; Kirner and Kirner 2005; Mengoni and Germani 2006; Rehn et al. 2004; Ritchie et al. 2002) in which the interactivity, usefulness and added value of VR were demonstrated for various design and simulation scenarios.

Cuadrado et al. (2004) present an application for a car virtual prototype where manoeuvrability evaluation in a VE is carried out by integrating 3D visual and haptic feedback. The MBS model used to represent the flexibility of the parts within the VE clearly demonstrates the added value of integrating VR with simulation in order to optimise a design. Eberhard and Li (2006) also present MBS simulation and control applications using VR as a user interface. In both these cases, the MBS real-time simulations represent the main limitation. This paper presents a novel approach to simplifying MBS computations in the case of visual evaluation and modification of virtual mechanical systems; a key aspect of design not addressed before in this domain. The applications developed by the authors incorporate common interactive facilities offered by a virtual environment, e.g. stereoscopic visualisation in a CAVE-like immersive system, walk-through, interactive object handling. These have been developed in the wider context of the EU-funded project called IRMA (“A Reconfigurable Multi-purpose Virtual Reality System for Industrial Manufacturing Applications”) (Modern et al. 2003). The overall aim of this project was to improve manufacturing performance by developing systems based on VR which will enable and enhance the design, monitoring, safe control and operation of industrial design and manufacturing processes, as well as providing high-quality training for staff in the operation of industrial plants.

The interfaces presented in this paper combine various computer programs for the kinematic and dynamic analysis and simulation of mechanical systems with VR to facilitate design modification by interactively changing the positions of elements and joints or exporting simulation data into a VE for visual evaluation purposes.

When design modification in a VE is targeted, ideally a real-time computation will enable the user to visualise the effect of the modification on the design during the simulation and to quickly adopt solutions for improvement. However, the current computational power of MBS software is still limiting this possibility. For the kinematic and dynamic simulation of articulated mechanical systems several approaches are known, and a comparative evaluation of the efficiency of these is presented in Talaba and Antonya (2004). However, when real-time simulation is not possible, as far as the type of application allows, design evaluation in virtual environments (DEVE) could be achieved using the pre-recorded data alternative.

In this paper both types of applications are presented together with an assessment of the potential of the various dynamic approaches for these kinds of applications. Firstly, a DEVE approach developed by the authors for civil engineering is presented. Then a real-time design modification in virtual environments (DMVE) is described following the classification proposed in Talaba and Antonya (2004). Finally a DMVE application for a car suspension mechanism is outlined.

Design evaluation in a virtual environment

Simulation in a VE provides significant added value in design evaluation especially in the case of civil engineering structures; for example, at the stage in which piping and cabling of the building are designed. In this domain, where VR-aided design tools have already been comprehensively researched (Ritchie et al. 2002), it is important to know the most stable elements of the building that can support the cables and pipes in order to avoid gas losses or electric fires in the event of an earthquake.

The VR interface brings advantages related to the evaluation of the design options at a real scale in real time. It also provides standard facilities such as walkthrough, freezing the system for design evaluation and making measurements.

For the MBS simulation, real life civil engineering metallic structures were used. Such structures are usually designed as mechanical systems with zero degrees of freedom, although mobile joints such as those used in typical mechanical mechanisms are also involved, e.g. revolute and spherical (Antonya and Talaba 2004). Zero degrees-of-freedom allows the engineer to precisely design the force directions in the various branches of the metallic structure. In the first stage of design, the structure is represented as a mechanism which can transmit vertical and horizontal forces. In the subsequent stage, the structure’s mobility is cancelled by adding further bodies (braces) into the system. In this way, the load directions are well established from the very beginning of the process, and the structural role of each element is carefully determined. For the purpose of this research, a unified software scheme for VR-based simulation was conceived with the software developed incorporating three modules devoted to the three main stages in model definition and simulation, namely: pre-processing, processing and post-processing. The VR system is integrated into the interactive user interface modules for pre- and post-processing (Fig. 1).

For the purpose of visualisation in a VE, a VRML file format is employed. A specific problem in DEVE applications is the difficulty of converting graphic scenes in VRML format and communicating them in real time to the VE. In order to evaluate this limitation, this research included two cases: (1) the full scene approach in which the solid model of the system was entirely transferred to the virtual world and (2) the multi-particle system (MPS) approach in which the systems have been represented graphically by a collection of spheres allowing automatic transfer to the VE of simplified geometry. For the dynamic simulation module (Fig. 1) the work included two parallel approaches, one for each case: (1) the utilisation of a commercial solver using the MBS approach and (2) the development of new software based on the MPS approach. The latter allows an easy association of the spheres to the flexible configuration of the various elements of the mechanical system. For both approaches a pre-processing software module and a common post-processing software module have been developed in order to allow integration and communication with the IRMA VR core software (Modern et al. 2003).

The MBS approach

For the MBS approach the ADAMS™ analytical engineering software package has been used (Hibbeler 2001); this considers the mechanical system as a collection of interconnected bodies represented by equations motion as:

$$ \left\{ {\begin{array}{*{20}c} {{[J][\ifmmode\expandafter\ddot\else\expandafter\"\fi{q}] = [\psi ],}} \\ {{[m][\ifmmode\expandafter\ddot\else\expandafter\"\fi{q}] - [J]^{T} [\lambda ] = [Q_{{{\text{ex}}}} ].}} \\ \end{array} } \right. $$
(1)

In (1) the kinematic constraints corresponding to the joints are represented by the algebraic equations of the generalised accelerations \( {\left[ {\ifmmode\expandafter\ddot\else\expandafter\"\fi{q}} \right]} \) and the internal forces are included in the generalised forces vector [Q ex].

The internal forces introduced by the flexible beams are modelled as “beam” entities, which introduce spring-damping forces on all six degrees of freedom of the 3D space in the form:

$$ [F] = [k][\delta ] + [c][\ifmmode\expandafter\dot\else\expandafter\.\fi{\delta }], $$
(2)

in which [k] is the stiffness matrix, [δ] is the deformation vector, [c] is the damping matrix, \( {\left[ {\ifmmode\expandafter\dot\else\expandafter\.\fi{\delta }} \right]} \) is the deformation speed of the beam and \( {\left[ F \right]} = {\left[ {F_{x} \cdots F_{y} \cdots F_{z} \cdots M_{x} \cdots M_{y} \cdots M_{z} } \right]}^{{\text{T}}} \) is the vector of the spring-damping force incorporating directional forces (F) and moments (M). The stiffness and damping constants from (2) are determined with relationships that depend on the shape and dimensions of the real beam (in section and length), as well as materials used. Thus, the geometric input data of the beam model for the MBS software simulation is limited to the description of the profile and the connection points with the adjacent bodies. In principle, modelling a flexible beam in this application required its division into a number of rigid segments, linked by elastic beams.

In order to illustrate the modelling steps and feasibility of the MBS simulation approach, a simplified metallic structure was selected from a real life project (Fig. 2). The metallic structure is part of an industrial plant and includes 6 columns, 6 beams and 4 braces. These elements are made from steel laminated profiles of ‘I’ beam section, 205 × 210 mm2 for the columns (marked with 1), 107 × 403 mm2 for beams (2) and 105 × 107 mm2 for braces (3). The dimensions of the metallic structure simulated are: 20 m length, 10 m depth and 14 m high. In the corners of the structure the different kinds of elements are linked with mechanical revolute joints. In order to prevent the structure having mobility, braces are incorporated into different perpendicular frames of the structure. The division of the constructive elements into rigid parts is made such as to obtain segments of 2 m length. In this way, the columns have each been divided into 7 rigid parts, the beams into 5 parts and the braces into 9 rigid bodies. The building foundation is modelled as a rigid body to which ground motion is applied (the earthquake’s ground motion). The columns, i.e. the first segments, are linked by spherical joints to the ground. The first and the last rigid segment of each beam are articulated to the columns by revolute joints. The axes of these joints are perpendicular on the plane of the adjacent bodies, i.e. the beam’s rigid segment and the column’s rigid segment. The braces are linked to the columns through revolute joints in a similar way to the beams. For example, in corner A from Fig. 3 three revolute joints are illustrated: two between the beam segments (2) and column segment (1), respectively, and the revolute joint between the bracing segment (3) and the column (1). The model obtained has 109 rigid ungrounded bodies, 20 revolute joints, 6 spherical joints and 530 degrees-of-freedom. Apart from the foundation body and the lower-end segments of the beams, columns and braces, all the other segments are not kinematically constrained but are constrained only by internally generated forces (flexible links). The roof weight of 150 N/m2 has been taken into account by applying a supplementary mass of 10 kg to each beam. For the purpose of the simulation the “earthquake” was introduced as a simple harmonic excitation force on the foundation of the building. This body was linked to the ground by a planar mechanical joint in the horizontal plane, whereas the excitation considered was on the direction of the foundation rectangle diagonal with amplitude 15 kN and frequency 2 Hz. A deformed state of the system is presented in Fig. 4.

As well as this, a real-life building was fully modelled and simulated in order to demonstrate the method for large systems (Fig. 5). This steel-structure building has a larger number of elements and was modelled as follows: 393 moving parts (not including the foundation body), 133 revolute joints, 22 spherical joints and other 10 fixed joints for the roof elements. The number of the degrees of freedom of the entire model was 1,566. The excitation taken into consideration was a real earthquake of magnitude of 6.5° on Richter scale, and the displacement of the base was imposed accordingly. In this case the peak values of the acceleration were: 0.31 m/s2 (for vertical motion), 0.77 and 0.52 m/s2 for horizontal motion and for the vertical displacement 1.6, 5.4 and 2.5 cm (two directions in the horizontal plane). The simulation proved that the structure was easily supported with the most important displacements being recorded at the roof level. A simulation of the building state resulting from the ADAMS data was obtained and observed in a CAVE-like VR system with three screen projected walls and is shown in Fig. 5. The user is located in the CAVE and is equipped with data-gloves and is positionally tracked via an optical tracking system.

For the virtual reality simulation of this building’s behaviour the IRMA VR-developed software was used (Modern et al. 2003). The core integration module is the Delfoi Integrator™, a PC-based message broker used to link a VE and a production/failure database scenario for different simulations. This links an Excel database containing the pre-computed data history of the modelled steel structure with the VRML model of the building. The DEVE module offers facilities to manipulate the simulation in a VE, freeze the system for measurements of earthquake effects at certain moments in time, zooming, setting up the observer location, loading the transparent model of the unaffected building and comparing this with the current simulation position (Fig. 6). These facilities were found to be very useful in the evaluation of the design and optimal choice of the piping and cabling paths to ensure maximum safety.

The multi-particle system (MPS) approach

For the same DEVE purpose, a second solver was developed based on the MPS approach, where the rigid bodies are modelled as sub-systems of mass particles which conserve the original mass properties of the body (Talaba and Antonya 2004). This requires a minimum number of four equivalent mass points in 3D space for each rigid part. The beams, columns and braces have been divided in the same way as for the MBS approach and each rigid part modelled with a set of 6 mass points to facilitate the definition of the mobile and flexible connections between the various bodies; the 6 mass points themselves being located at the extremities in order to facilitate the definition of the spring elements between the two adjacent parts (Fig. 7). The multi-particle model considers the mechanical system as a collection of particles subject to a set of absolute and relative constraints. The main difference with respect to conventional multi-body models is where overall dynamic model comprises point masses instead of bodies. From the visualisation viewpoint the VRML transfer can be done automatically because the spheres represent particles or point masses, and the rotational motion which usually characterises the 3D bodies becomes irrelevant for this case. The mass matrix and external force vector are computed for each particle without reference to any body reference frames making the mass matrix very simple. As presented in Talaba and Antonya (2004), the mechanism representation includes a particle-based model for each rigid body and point contact models for each type of joint. The rigid body model consists of a set of particles separated by constant distances, each particle being associated with a concentrated mass according to the inertial equivalence with the real object.

Once the positions of the particles are established in the body frame, the point masses can be easily obtained from the inertial equivalence conditions.

For dynamic simulation, the equations have the same general form as for the MBS model:

$$ m\ifmmode\expandafter\ddot\else\expandafter\"\fi{q} - J^{T} \lambda = Q_{{{\text{ex}}}} , $$
(3)

in which the mass matrix (m) is a diagonal matrix:

$$ m = {\text{diag}}{\left[ {\begin{array}{*{20}c} {{m_{1} }} & {{m_{1} }} & {{m_{1} }} & {{m_{2} }} & {{m_{2} }} & {{m_{2} }} & {{m_{3} }} & {{m_{3} }} & {{m_{3} }} & {{...}} & {{m_{F} }} & {{m_{F} }} & {{m_{F} }} \\ \end{array} } \right]}. $$
(4)

The Lagrange multipliers (λ) include the joint reaction forces (including no torques since the rotation of point masses is no longer relevant) and also the constant distance reaction forces between the particles of the rigid bodies.

The application taken into consideration was the same as for the multi-body approach (the structural cell of a building, Fig. 2). The input data to generate the VRML file only includes the number of mass-points into which the entire metallic structure has been divided.

The multi-particle model developed for the structural cell contains the following elements: 745 mass-points corresponding to 113 solid elements, 576 translational springs and dampers, 20 revolute joints, 6 spherical joints, 1 planar joint, 1,557 constant distance constraints.

For the VR presentation of the results a graphical user interface has been developed (Fig. 8) to link the MBS/MPS solver to the IRMA VR software and enables various tools to help engineers compare different designs and evaluate simulation results.

In order to evaluate various designs, the input data for the solver can be changed with the interface and, after re-computing the structure’s behaviour, the new result can be put alongside the previous results in the VE and visually compared. In addition, magnification factors have been introduced in order to scale buildings of different dimensions to be able to enhance design comparison. In Fig. 9 a VR simulation of the structure is shown as displayed by the post-processing module. The spheres corresponding to the point-masses are coloured according to the magnitude of the forces acting on them and provide an indication of the levels of local stress.

Comparison between MBS and MPS solvers

The computation times for the two approaches for a 1 s simulation in 100 steps and the same external load were as follows:

  • ADAMS, 1.02 min (Adams–Bashforth–Moulton integration method);

  • C++ application, 18.7 min (backwards Euler integration method);

  • MATLAB-version of the MPS solver, 20.77 min (backwards Euler integration method).

The MPS approach is obviously computationally slower, because the number of equations is much higher than the MBS formulation. However, in case of similar implementations for large systems the difference is much smaller, as shown in Talaba and Antonya (2004). In the case presented a body is represented by 6 mass points which generate 6 × 3 = 18 differential equations, plus 12 algebraic constant distance equations to model the rigid body conditions, so that there are 18 + 12 = 30 differential algebraic equations (DAEs) per body, compared to 6 DAEs per body using MBS. Although from a general perspective the MPS approach is attractive, for real-time simulation it has a disadvantage in the increased number of entities describing the model (for each body at least four points are required, while in the MBS approach one body equals one entity). This requires longer times for the post-processing stage as well as for communicating the results and updating the geometry. However, as only one type of geometric entity is involved, the up-dating process can be done automatically.

The post-processor developed, called VR-Post, allows the user to present the results in using approaches as well as to freeze the system in a desired state, take measurements of displacements, display the strength of the beam segments in a similar manner as in conventional FEM packages (colour elements), walk into the structure and “see” the behaviour of the structure during the earthquake (Fig. 6). This set of VR facilities offers the user the possibility to evaluate the behaviour of various building elements during an earthquake and take appropriate design and manufacturing decisions for building reinforcement and assembly or to determine a choice of paths for force transmission.

Design modification in a virtual environment

Making a design modification on a mechanical system means that the input data file, which contains all the relevant information, has to be changed accordingly and, usually, the simulation should be run again with a new set of data as if it were a totally new system. The novel alternative proposed in this paper is to reuse the results of the initial system and compute only the modifications with an incremental computational approach. In case of mechanical systems, without altering the number of bodies (elements) which define it and the type of connections between them, a design modification can be done by modifying the position of a joint or modifying the position of a body. It is well known that the most common joints employed in planar linkages are revolute and translational. In order to enhance the efficiency for design modification, the incremental computation allows the calculation of a modified simulation using the initial structure thread, in which some of the variables are already available from the initial evaluation. Since no changes have been considered in the structure of the system, the modifications in the input data file will depend on the method used for describing the system as the methods presented use different sets of geometric parameters.

Design modification in multi-body system formulation

Due to the intensive computational effort required for the MBS analysis, design modification is simply not feasible via a re-computing approach; therefore, some form of shortcut calculation needs to be used. In this section, a technique to avoid the entire re-computing of the model’s kinematics is proposed. As the Cartesian coordinates of the elements are used mostly for the description of the system (Haugh 1989), the generalised coordinates of the system are the position and orientation of each mobile element; most often the origin coordinates and the orientation angle with respect to the global reference frame. Not all the coordinates are independent because of the geometrical constraints introduced by the joints. Each constraint is represented by a geometric condition written mathematically as an algebraic equation linking the generalised coordinates of the adjacent bodies. The structure of the entire system can be described by the position of the elements and at the coordinates of the points defining the joint.

Modifying the position of a revolute joint implies modification of the local coordinates of the two points which define the revolute joint, whilst other data relating to the mechanism remains unaffected; in the constraint equations of revolute joints it is usually considered that two points of two bodies are in the same place during the simulation. The new coordinates of the two points (P i , P j ) in their local frame (Fig. 10) can be computed knowing their original coordinates (x iPi , y iPi , x jPj , x Pj j,), the orientation angle of the two bodies (ϕ i , ϕ j ) and the revolute joint’s modification values (Δx r, Δy r):

$$ {\left[ {\begin{array}{*{20}c} {{x_{{{\text{P}}_{i} }} ^{i} }} \\ {{y_{{{\text{P}}_{i} }} ^{i} }} \\ \end{array} } \right]}_{{{\text{new}}}} = {\left[ {\begin{array}{*{20}c} {{x_{{{\text{P}}_{i} }} ^{i} }} \\ {{y_{{{\text{P}}_{i} }} ^{i} }} \\ \end{array} } \right]} + {\left[ {\begin{array}{*{20}c} {{\cos \varphi _{i} }} & {{ - \sin \varphi _{i} }} \\ {{\sin \varphi _{i} }} & {{\cos \varphi _{i} }} \\ \end{array} } \right]} \cdot {\left[ {\begin{array}{*{20}c} {{\Delta x_{{\text{r}}} }} \\ {{\Delta y_{{\text{r}}} }} \\ \end{array} } \right]} $$
(5)
$$ {\left[ {\begin{array}{*{20}c} {{x_{{{\text{P}}_{j} }} ^{j} }} \\ {{y_{{{\text{P}}_{j} }} ^{j} }} \\ \end{array} } \right]}_{{{\text{new}}}} = {\left[ {\begin{array}{*{20}c} {{x_{{{\text{P}}_{j} }} ^{j} }} \\ {{y_{{{\text{P}}_{j} }} ^{j} }} \\ \end{array} } \right]} + {\left[ {\begin{array}{*{20}c} {{\cos \varphi _{j} }} & {{ - \sin \varphi _{j} }} \\ {{\sin \varphi _{j} }} & {{\cos \varphi _{j} }} \\ \end{array} } \right]} \cdot {\left[ {\begin{array}{*{20}c} {{\Delta x_{{\text{r}}} }} \\ {{\Delta y_{{\text{r}}} }} \\ \end{array} } \right]} $$
(6)

In the case of a translational joint, modifications can be introduced in the same manner. The translational joint is usually defined by four points (P i , Q i , P j , Q j ), two on each body which lie on the same line. Modifying the position of the joint in a parallel position has no affect on the kinematics and little on the dynamics. A more radical affect on the behaviour can be achieved by rotating the joint’s line.

The consequence of the modification of a body’s position or orientation angle will be that other elements linked to it will have their geometry altered. Since joints are described using points only the coordinates of those points will be modified in the input data file describing the modified body’s joints. The corresponding positions of external loads, springs and damper are also described in this way. If these elements’ positions are influenced by the position of the body on which they act then the coordinates of those points will also change.

For example, if the position of body i is modified by Δx e , Δy e (Fig. 11) and is linked with a revolute joint on body j then only P j ’s coordinates will change; P i ’s coordinates, in the local reference frame, remain the same. The new coordinate of P j can be written as:

$$ {\left[ {\begin{array}{*{20}c} {{x_{{{\text{P}}_{j} }} ^{j} }} \\ {{y_{{{\text{P}}_{j} }} ^{j} }} \\ \end{array} } \right]}_{{{\text{new}}}} = {\left[ {\begin{array}{*{20}c} {{x_{{{\text{P}}_{j} }} ^{j} }} \\ {{y_{{{\text{P}}_{j} }} ^{j} }} \\ \end{array} } \right]} - {\left[ {\begin{array}{*{20}c} {{\Delta x_{e} ^{j} }} \\ {{\Delta y_{e} ^{j} }} \\ \end{array} } \right]} = {\left[ {\begin{array}{*{20}c} {{x_{{{\text{P}}_{j} }} ^{j} }} \\ {{y_{{{\text{P}}_{{_{j} }} }} ^{j} }} \\ \end{array} } \right]} - {\left[ {\begin{array}{*{20}c} {{\cos \varphi _{j} }} & {{ - \sin \varphi _{j} }} \\ {{\sin \varphi _{j} }} & {{\cos \varphi _{j} }} \\ \end{array} } \right]} \cdot {\left[ {\begin{array}{*{20}c} {{\Delta x_{e} }} \\ {{\Delta y_{e} }} \\ \end{array} } \right]} $$
(7)

Other modifications in the position of joints can be written in the same manner (Antonya 2004).

Design modification using the multi-particle system approach

In the case of the MPS a similar technique can be used because it is based on the coordinates of points in the global reference frame (Talaba and Antonya 2004). Since within the VE the user is modifying the coordinates of some points, all of these modifications will be reflected in the input data file by incrementally modifying the coordinates of the points involved:

$$ {\left[ {\begin{array}{*{20}c} {{x_{{{\text{P}}_{i} }} }} \\ {{y_{{{\text{P}}_{i} }} }} \\ \end{array} } \right]}_{{{\text{new}}}} = {\left[ {\begin{array}{*{20}c} {{x_{{{\text{P}}_{i} }} }} \\ {{y_{{{\text{P}}_{i} }} }} \\ \end{array} } \right]} + {\left[ {\begin{array}{*{20}c} {{\Delta x_{{{\text{P}}_{i} }} }} \\ {{\Delta y_{{{\text{P}}_{i} }} }} \\ \end{array} } \right]} $$
(8)

Therefore, the MPS formulation can provide a straightforward use for DMVE applications.

Interactive design modification with MBS and MPS solvers

In the interactive design modification process the efficiency of the dynamic solver plays a crucial part in achieving realism. In comparing both solvers, two solvers and two applications were developed. In both cases the mechanical system was considered as a collection of rigid bodies and of mass-points connected by various constrains. The applications are processed as an input text file containing all of the data needed relating to the mechanism in the simulation process. This file contains data about the analysis type (kinematic or dynamic), the time interval of the simulation (including the computation step), the initial position and orientation of each element (in the MBS case), the coordinates of points which describe various elements (joints, forces, springs, dampers), the joint types (revolute, translational and composite joints), driving motions, mass properties of the elements and external forces, springs and dampers (Antonya 2004).

The programs developed use a generalised Cartesian coordinate approach (Haugh 1989), and the joint constraints on the motions of the bodies are formulated in terms of position and, in the MBS approach, the orientation of a mobile reference frame assigned to each element. In the computational modules (2) and (5) are solved with Adams–Bashforth–Moulton predictor–corrector method, and Baumgarte stabilisation for reducing the constraints’ violation (Haugh 1989; Lin and Huang 2002). The design modifications can be made interactively with the mouse using touch sensors implemented in the VRML file. The user can modify the position of bodies and joints with a VR device such as a dataglove, Phantom or a 3D mouse during the computational processes. The communication with the VE is provided through Matlab’s Virtual Reality Toolbox. This resulted in the integration of a near real-time dynamics and kinematics computational engine within the interactive VRML world.

The computational time needed for the MBS formulation was 12% less than for the MPS model, although the dynamic analysis and the implementation of the modifications were much easier in the latter.

In Figs. 12 and 13 an interactive simulation frame in the VE is presented for an automotive suspension mechanism, where the revolute joint’s position of the lower arm can be interactively changed with a VR input device during the computational process.

For the MPS model in Fig. 13 the lighter spheres are added with the purpose of reconstructing the original shape of the elements involved and do not influence the dynamic behaviour of the system. The number of spheres depends on how accurately the user intends to reconstruct the original shape. If a certain region or a point behaviour is under investigation, then supplemental spheres are only needed in that region. Both the 3D visualisation and haptic feedback provide a natural, easy and intuitive environment for an engineer to work in, allowing rapid testing and evaluation of several concepts and geometric solutions.

Conclusions

The effective application of simulation in an immersive virtual environment for product evaluation and modification has been presented. New mathematical approaches have been presented and it has been shown that the usual dynamic techniques could be used, i.e. MBS and MPS. More importantly, for design modification an incremental formulation must be used in order to enhance the simulation’s real-time efficiency.

Two applications relevant to manufacturing have been presented in order to illustrate the concepts, the interfaces and the interaction metaphors: a complex civil engineering structure, part of a larger IRMA VR package for manufacturing applications for DEVE module and a car suspension mechanism for the DMVE module. It has been successfully demonstrated that simulation can be linked to VR, and new capabilities are available to the engineer working within such a design environment. However, some useful conclusions have also been developed with regard to the choice of MBS/MPS:

  • For the design evaluation process the MBS approach is much more suitable due to the fact that the original shapes of the mechanical system elements are maintained. However, when modification is involved, the shapes of the parts have to be changed which is in turn limited by the standard facilities offered by the commercial software.

  • A way of overcoming this disadvantage is to employ an MPS approach. Although the computation time increases, the analysis is much easier for both the dynamic calculations and the implementation of updates in a VR environment. For a certain region of the system more points can be added and their path can be visually followed in the VE if required.

For minor design changes, the nature of the MBS and MPS systems can be modified by moving one or more bodies or joints; by doing this the entire kinematic or dynamic behaviour of the system can be changed. The modification itself can be easily followed and evaluated in the VE due to the facilities offered by the VR interface: animations can be superimposed, various elements can be hidden, the transparency of the models can be modified for better visual evaluation or changes can be made interactively. The visualisation software also offers measuring tools for distances and angles. As a result, VEs can be developed in such a way that the entire design process can be carried out without having to leave the environment.

The research and applications presented in this paper demonstrate the practicality, flexibility and versatility of VR technology in interactive design evaluation and modification. However, the limited computer processing available for real-time dynamic simulation is still restricting the range of applications to models of moderated size for real-time interactive design modification. In this context, the methodologies and tools described in this paper are candidates for implementation in real-time design and manufacturing software applications for the generation and analysis of virtual prototypes.
